prompt_data.system_prompt: You are an expert in discourse analysis. First, answer Yes/No to each: Is a social group referenced? Is an us-vs-them contrast present? Is the group positioned as inferior/excluded/outside belonging? Only if all 3 are Yes, classify as 'Othering'. Otherwise classify as 'None'. If uncertain, choose 'None'. Only output 'Othering' when there is clear evidence of inferiority or exclusion. Answer in JSON format only with 'Othering' or 'None' for 'label' and a short sentence explaining your decision process in 'reasoning' and identify the target group in 'target'. Context keywords should help you understand the meaning of the text, but do not assume any additional information.
prompt_data.question: Is this comment othering?

3.text: “Hi Kpop girl can I send you a pic of g-dragon” “Woohoo I can’t wait! Please send it right away!” “Here you go” *sends a pic of g-dragon with no make up* “Ugh! No you spoilt my day! Hehe!”

annotation.label: None
annotation.reasoning: The conversation is about a Kpop fan sharing a picture of G-Dragon with another fan. The tone is informal and friendly, with no evidence of inferiority or exclusion.

4.text: Bruh, I don't even like g-dragon but his comment is accurate af in describing how you'd come off as some socially awkward neckbeard if you talked like that to a girl.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: The text implies that someone who talks like that to a girl would come off as socially awkward and inferior, positioning the group as outside belonging.

1.text: How to spoil a kpop fangirl's day. Tell her you want to send her a pic of g dragon. She'll be expecting something like this, but no. Send his candid pics without makeup. Amazing what makeup can do for guys too, not just girls.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: The text creates an us-vs-them contrast by referencing a specific group (kpop fangirls) and positioning them as inferior or outside belonging through mocking their expectations and preferences.

2.text: “Hi Kpop girl can I send you a pic of g-dragon?” “Uhhh ok” (what the hell? this guy is so weird) “Here you go” *sends pic of g-dragon with no makeup* “Uhh thanks I guess” (Jesus I hope he never talks to me again)

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: The speaker is clearly positioning the Kpop fan as inferior or outside their social circle through mocking and dismissive language.

5.text: "Bruh", you're stupid if you think I talked to any of my friends in the manner he posted. I wrote a condensed version of what I did, not verbatim. End result was just people being surprised by how k pop idols look without make up, nothing awkward. I think people on this subreddit project too much when it comes to social awkwardness based on their own inadequacies.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: The text implies that people who project social awkwardness are doing so based on their own inadequacies, positioning them as inferior or outside belonging.

6.text: > if you think I talked to any of my friends in the manner he posted. Good thing I don't actually think that, but the fact that you're even fantasising and joking about it says a lot. Nah, you come off as a loser who doesn't know how to speak to women without scaring them off. That's a sad fact man. Now bye loser

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: The text contains an us-vs-them contrast by calling someone a 'loser' and implying they are not part of the in-group due to their social behavior.
annotation.target: someone who interacts with women in a socially awkward manner

8.text: I disagree with your first para, but I see your point for the rest of what you wrote. People need to realise identity is fluid and constructed. Rabid nationalism is a disease that needs to be addressed.

21.text: The % of Muslims is similar in both countries. The only *significant* difference is that Singapore has a much higher % of Christians and Catholics. So just to clarify - people from those two groups are bigots that preventing social progress. Let's call a spade a spade. >might not be worth removing a law that isn't enforced anyway. 22.text: > The % of Muslims is similar in both countries. The only significant difference is that Singapore has a much higher % of Christians and Catholics. So just to clarify - people from those two groups are bigots that preventing social progress. Let's call a spade a spade. Using your reasoning, the higher % of Christians and Catholics are also responsible for reducing the prevalence of sex crimes. If you use that line of thinking it cuts both ways.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: The text implies that people from Christian and Catholic groups are bigots preventing social progress, positioning them as inferior or outside belonging. Additionally, it suggests that these groups are responsible for reducing the prevalence of sex crimes, which can be seen as exclusionary.

23.text: >Using your reasoning, the higher % of Christians and Catholics are also responsible for reducing the prevalence of sex crimes. If you use that line of thinking it cuts both ways. Do Christians and Catholics speak out against sex crimes more than any other group in Singapore? Meanwhile, we know for a fact that those two religions are vehemently opposed to homosexuality. Please just look at things like the AWARE saga, NLB book fiasco or the Wear White campaign. So yeah, your argument makes no sense, because there's correlation for one issue while none for the other.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: The text implies that Christians and Catholics are more responsible for reducing sex crimes, but also mentions their opposition to homosexuality, creating an us-vs-them contrast and positioning the group as inferior or excluded due to their conservative views on homosexuality.

24.text: Your thinking is too simplistic. Just because people don't vehemently speak out against homosexuality does not mean that they support LGBT. The method by which you "determined" correlation is laughably dumb. Saudi Arabia has no Catholics and Christians, why don't they have gay marriage as well? But its okay. You can continue labouring under the delusion that all that stands in the way of gay marriage are Christians and Catholics.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: The text implies that Christians and Catholics are the primary obstacles to gay marriage, positioning them as inferior or outside the norm. It also creates an us-vs-them contrast between these groups and others, including Muslims.

25.text: You are backtracking. Someone posted a bunch of reasons why Singapore as a whole may be opposed to LGBT outside of religion and your response was this: > "The only significant difference is that Singapore (as compared to India) has a much higher % of Christians and Catholics. So just to clarify - people from those two groups are bigots that preventing social progress. Let's call a spade a spade." Go ahead and try to shift the goal posts into "whether Christians and Catholics are opposed to LGBT". I'm done here.

annotation.label: Othering
annotation.reasoning: The text implies Christians and Catholics in Singapore are opposed to LGBT, positioning them as bigots and preventing social progress, thus creating an us-vs-them contrast and excluding the group from belonging.

26.text: Ceddya's point is that there is a much higher % of Christians in Singapore, while the % of Muslims in Singapore and India are similar. Saudi Arabia on the other hand is practically the center of Islam, so it's not an apples-to-apples comparison.

annotation.reasoning: The text does not clearly evidence inferiority or exclusion of any group. It presents a comparison between percentages of Christians and Muslims in different countries without positioning one as superior or inferior to the other.

Depending on how you look at it, you can see this as discrimination against either gender.
